data.title: Fighter's History: King of Fighters '94
data.meta_description:
To deny that SNK's beloved King of Fighters franchise is one of the most prolific and prestigious videogame series of the last decade would border on negligence. But to assume that the KOF name still doesn't have any life left in it would be an even bigger mistake. Due out on October 12, King of Fighters: Maximum Impact is living proof of this fact as the worldwide favorite attempts to do something it has never done before: move into the third-dimension. Though it's true that the series has flirted with various other 3D elements before (KOF '99's backgrounds are a great example), the franchise has never gone entirely 3D. But as the old saying continually goes, "There's a first time for everything."

But how did the King of Fighters brand get so popular and respected in the first place? What was it about SNK's combination of Art of Fighting and Fatal Fury characters that helped propel it to a reputable level only previously enjoyed by games like Mortal Kombat and Street Fighter II? And how is it that a series with minimal advertising or editorial exposure has successfully lasted more than ten sequels across various different platforms and multiple console generations? Truthfully, the answer to those questions is a simple one: it's fun. As rudimentary as that explanation may be, it's the truth. Sure you can try and overcomplicate matters by talking about new additions to various fighting systems, cutting edge character designs, or other such things of the like, but at the end of the day, the fun is all you need. And fun is what this series has.

To celebrate (and to serve as a special tribute to a series that has helped keep the 2D fighting genre alive for more than a decade), we've teamed up with our friends at SNK NeoGeo USA to present a series of special articles honoring the glorious games of the days now past. Dubbed "Maximum Impact," this retrospective series will take a look back at the various games that created the franchise as we know it today, and help you to understand what's changed; how it's changed; and why it's changed leading up to the release of October's King of Fighters: Maximum Impact for the PlayStation 2.

Now keep in mind, this article isn't meant to be a one-stop end-all/be-all encyclopedia for all things King of Fighters -- there are plenty of other places on the web for that. Instead, our articles are meant to be taken as an abridged look into the past: covering significant changes in the series' history and storylines that are meant to help an all-new generation of fighting fans understand a little but more about the toughest competition that the Street Fighter series has ever had.

For our first installment, we'll be taking a look at the first titles in the KOF series, King of Fighters '94.

To celebrate (and to serve as a special tribute to a series that has helped keep the 2D fighting genre alive for more than a decade), we've teamed up with our friends at SNK NeoGeo USA to present a series of special articles honoring the glorious games of the days now past. Dubbed "Fighter's History," this retrospective series will take a look back at the various games that created the franchise as we know it today, and help you to understand what's changed; how it's changed; and why it's changed leading up to the release of November's King of Fighters 02/03 for the Xbox.

Rugal Berstein

Now keep in mind, this article isn't meant to be a one-stop end-all/be-all encyclopedia for all things King of Fighters -- there are plenty of other places on the web for that. Instead, our articles are meant to be taken as an abridged look into the past: covering significant changes in the series' history and storylines that are meant to help an all-new generation of fighting fans understand a little but more about the toughest competition that the Street Fighter series has ever had.

For our first installment, we'll be taking a look at the first titles in the KOF series, King of Fighters '94.

King of Fighters '94

Though technically the beginning of the KOF franchise, King of Fighters '94 still had quite a bit of history behind it. In fact, the old SNK classic Fatal Fury is where it all originally began. As it turns out, the Southtown badass himself, Geese Howard started the tournament when he used the King of Fighters competition to eliminate any potential threats to his position as the city's most powerful man (plus, he used the gambling profits to fuel his criminal empire). And for quite some time Geese ruled with an iron first. That is, until the son of one of his victims (Jeff Bogard) named Terry Bogard came along and whipped his butt all the way out of a skyscraper window -- ending the KOF tournament and giving Terry and his brother Andy peace. Or so they thought...

The very next year, a mysterious new honcho by the name of Wolfgang Krauser became the new master of the King of Fighters tournament and made it his personal mission to defeat the man who destroyed his predecessor. And though Terry kicked his butt too, the seeds were planted for the first "official" King of Fighters game.

In it, a third man had taken over leadership of the King of Fighter tournament, a super-powerful Black Market baddy named Rugal Berstein. To make things more interesting, though, Rugal made a significant change to the rules -- requiring participants to fight in teams rather than individually. If one person lost a round against one opponent the next would take his place, and so on and so on. Once all three members of a team were defeated, their time in the tournament was over and the winning team would move on. The premise was quite simple really and it set the stage rather nicely for KOF '94.

Winning the KOF tournament wasn't exactly roses, however, as the eventual victorious team (Team Japan, which consisted of original characters Kyo Kusanagi, Goro Daimon, and Benimaru Nikkaido) would have to square off against the tournament ringleader himself, Rugal. The stakes were quite high too -- as Rugal would add the fallen foes to his collection of steel-encased fighters that he had previously defeated in is career. Only when Kyo noticed that his father Saisyu was among the many statues aboard Rugal's personal ship known as the Black Noah was the team inspired enough to overcome Rugal's considerable strength and defeat him -- blowing up the ship in the process and obliteration Rugal Bernstein along with it.

As a game, the original King of Fighters may not be as advanced as most of today's flashy fighting games, but at the time it was actually quite advanced. In fact, it was the first game of its type to offer three-on-three battles (which have since become commonplace in several genre titles since) and it legitimized the idea of borrowing characters from several existing franchises to make one big super crossover that fans of various backgrounds could enjoy. The Art of Fighting, Fatal Fury, Athena, and Ikari Warriors characters assembled together in a single game was considered a blockbuster move, and it quickly gained notoriety among those series fans as well as hardcore fighting nuts looking for alternatives to Street Fighter II.

In terms of its mechanics, KOF '94 was essentially a cross between Fatal Fury and Art of Fighting; with a much speedier response time than either. Granted, it wasn't as quick as Street Fighter, but each combatant still offered as many as five special moves apiece with familiar fireball and sonic boom motions that allowed veterans of Capcom's classic to become more easily acclimated. Unfortunately, the game did employ several odd "upside down fireball" maneuvers that created strange control hitches that affected your maneuverability and jumping prowess in addition to making for a rather limited combo system.

But even with these restrictions, King of Fighters '94 still offered a number of new features that weren't available with Ryu and Ken. User-controlled super move charges and the ability to sidestep projectiles, for example, were a terrific ideas that really opened up the possibilities. While the much more detailed backgrounds helped put it on par with the Street Fighter series as a viable substitute.

But that was just the beginning for SNK and its soon to be legendary series, as there were still much more impressive things still to come. Next time, we'll explore the next step in this fighting evolution with King of Fighters '95! See you then.
